iii
United Nations E-Government Survey 2010
Foreword
e high demand for e-government knowledge
and skills on the part of Member States has increased
considerably in recent years. is upward trend in e-
government development has accelerated despite, or
maybe in part also due to, the current nancial crisis
and the pressing need for governments to be compe-
tent, transparent, accessible and ecient. e crisis
makes a compelling case for e-government. e de-
mand for social support has increased dramatically
while revenues have declined precipitously. Public
sector commitments to stimulus packages and -
nancial sector support have yielded debt levels that
may take a very long time to reduce.
Member States have had to coordinate, make hard
choices and weigh spending options very carefully.
But we must also consider in this moment that there
is a reason why e-government matters beyond the
need to maximize eciency, or even beyond engag-
ing citizens in urgent questions of public policy. e
compelling factor and the bitter lesson learned from
the crisis is that trust matters and lack of condence
in government, as in markets, can lead to calamity.
e capacity to respond under dicult conditions
and deliver expected results are cornerstones of eec-
tive government and a foundation of public trust.
The 2010 edition of the United Nations
E-Goernment Survey, the h in a series begun
in 2003, makes the case that e-government should
play an ever-greater role in development. Many
countries have made tremendous strides in the last
two years, due in part to recent, exciting advances
in the diusion of technology. With its respon-
sive, citizen-centric qualities, I rmly believe that
e-government can make a decisive contribution to
the achievement of the MDGs, particularly in de-
veloping regions.
is publication can become a useful reference
to guide development eorts at international, re-
gional and local levels. 
Sha Zukang
Under-Secretary-General for
Economic and Social Aairs
E-government – once a bold experiment and now an important tool for public sector
transformation – has progressed to the point where it is now a force for eective gover-
nance and citizen participation, both at national and local levels. is is important. Until
governments have the capacity to lead development eorts and deliver services that fully
respond to the needs of citizens, the achievement of the internationally agreed devel-
opment goals will continue to elude us. With the Millennium Development Goal time
horizon of 2015 quickly approaching, it is no longer a question of whether we can aord
information and communications technology in health, education, environmental pro-
tection and a multitude of other areas, but where to deploy them rst and how rapidly
gains can be realized.
